Hero.junior: From zero-level to Junior in three months,

SchoolComparison.title: School
SchoolComparison.subtitle: Comparison
SchoolComparison.description: We have prepared a detailed comparison table for you, where all major programming schools are presented in comparison with ours.

description.item1: Every day you go to the bootcamp. The atmosphere and live communication help to focus and keep you motivated.
description.item2: Together with an offline group, but via Discord. Unlike online schools, you immediately get answers to all questions.
description.item3: Partly online, partly at the bootcamp. When you want to chat live, but are not ready to pay offline.
description.item4: You are away from home, but you want to study live - in a close cultural environment, with teachers from Russia.

QuestionsRemain.title: Is it difficult? Let's explain!
QuestionsRemain.subtitle: Leave a request - we will contact you via messenger.

conditions.link: terms for the transfer of information

ScheduleCard.text1: With a mentor. New theory, collaborative problem solving, checking homework
ScheduleCard.text3: With a mentor. Consolidation of material, analysis of difficult moments

Header.btn: I'd like to talk, call me

SchoolInfo.title: About
SchoolInfo.project: How did we create the project?
SchoolInfo.problem: What problems do await the newcomer?
SchoolInfo.web: How and why do we teach programming?

SchoolItemsProject.item1: Our project is based on the program of the American bootcamps. They have existed for ten years already and have a high percentage of graduates who found a job.
SchoolItemsProject.item2: We showed our program to developers who work for big IT companies to realize how it fits the requirements of these companies.
SchoolItemsProject.item3: Then we found like-minded people with experience in programming who were tired of writing code and wanted to connect with people — they were ready to become teachers. It turned out that their pedagogical skills were often lacking — despite them already studying trainees or teaching friends how to code. And we taught them to teach professionally.

FaqInfo.title: Frequently Asked Questions
FaqInfo.ask: Ask your question if you have not found the answer here
FaqInfo.requirements: What computer and operating system are needed?
FaqInfo.todo: What do you have to do before bootcamp?
FaqInfo.payment: How can I pay for bootcamp?

FaqRequirements.keyOne: Any laptop will fit if it's fast. If it slows down, better install Linux Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
FaqRequirements.keyTwo: Preferably to have Linux or macOS operating system to get used to working with the console.

FaqTodo.keyOne: Talk to your family and friends so they do not distract you while studying. All business after three or four months. It is important.
FaqTodo.keyTwo: Do our prep program. It is the way to practice the most complicated part for beginners, which means you get more out of the course. And you will also see if programming is OK for you as a new profession.
FaqTodo.keyThree: Make your financial safety pillow for five months. You will study for three months and then two months on average to job search: respond to vacancies, solve test tasks, and work off mistakes you made during interviews.
FaqTodo.keyFour: Set yourself up to work hard. Rest awaits you in a couple of years, not earlier.

FaqToPay.keyOne: You can pay in cash or by wire money transfer.
FaqToPay.keyTwo: There is a loan (installment plan) up to 2 years.

SchoolBegginer.header: So, you have decided to become a programmer. Usually, you start to watch Youtube, read articles, and maybe consult with your programmer friend. When the first information is inside your head, you understand — programming is too abstract. You have to define a bunch of new variables.
SchoolBegginer.item1: What industry do I want to work in?
SchoolBegginer.item2: How much time does it take to master?
SchoolBegginer.item3: How to study: on your own or go to school?
SchoolBegginer.item4: What is the best programming language for a beginner?
SchoolBegginer.item5: What technologies do you need to master in order to be hired?
SchoolBegginer.item6: What school is the best for studying? What is the difference between them? And which exactly fits me?
SchoolBegginer.item7: When do I have to finish studying and spend more time on the job search?
SchoolBegginer.item8: Why do employers ignore 95% of my applications? How to fix it?
SchoolBegginer.item9: What companies are good for career and professional growth?
SchoolBegginer.item10: How not to make suicide while reading a junior developer's vacancies?
SchoolBegginer.paragraph1: Graduates of other schools often go to us, because they have not found a job yet. They seem to already know something, but this is not enough to get a job.
SchoolBegginer.paragraph2: Sometimes you just need to sort out the mess in your head — clearly prioritize and recognize your strengths.
SchoolBegginer.paragraph3: We are happy to help such people, as we went through this hell.

SchoolItemStuding.header: We are not trying to put inside of your head as much as possible about programming — it is a road to depression, confirmed by our experience. We help you to start thinking like an engineer.
SchoolItemStuding.listTitle: What is engineering thinking in software:
SchoolItemStuding.item1: What questions do you have to resolve before starting a task?
SchoolItemStuding.item2: How to draw a flowchart so as not to get confused?
SchoolItemStuding.item3: How to highlight the main thing in a task?
SchoolItemStuding.item4: How much time to spend on a task?
SchoolItemStuding.item5: What do I need to figure out on my own? And when is it time to ask the elders?
SchoolItemStuding.item6: How to formulate questions so that colleagues understand you?
